about.header: Providing evidence to support your appeal
about.leadParagraph: Evidence is any information that supports your appeal, such as a letter, written statement or medical report. It all helps the tribunal understand the facts of your appeal.

intro.para1: You should provide evidence as soon as you can, if you have any. This is so the tribunal have time to consider it before making a decision on your benefit appeal.
intro.para2: You can provide evidence online or by post. Find out more about how to provide it at the bottom of this page.

medical.para1: This type of evidence helps the tribunal understand your condition from the perspective of a medical professional. For example, letters you have from your hospital consultant, doctor, physiotherapist or social worker. A useful letter explains how your condition affects your life at the time of the decision by DWP. Appointment letters are not useful.
medical.para2: If you don’t have any letters and you think one will help your appeal, you could ask the medical professional who has been treating your condition to write one. Please be aware they may charge you for this and they can take a long time to organise. The tribunal can’t pay for these.

statement.para1: Someone who lives with you or knows you well could write a statement. A useful statement describes how your condition affects your life and includes the types of activities you can and can’t do. It should be their own view.
statement.para2: It can written by hand or on a computer but it should be signed by the person who wrote it. It should also say what their relationship is to you.

photographic.para1: A useful photo will show how your condition affects your life, for example you could take a picture of any aids you use to help you move. Don’t send in photos of your body.

oral.para1: What you or anyone else says at a hearing (if you have one) is called ‘oral evidence’. The tribunal will use what is said to help them make a decision on your appeal.
oral.para2: If you have a hearing then you could invite someone who knows you well to come and tell the tribunal about your condition. You should check that they are willing to come and they are available on the day.

evidence.title: Providing evidence to support your appeal
evidence.entry: Evidence is any information that supports your side of the appeal, such as a letter, written statement or medical report. It can help the tribunal understand the facts of your appeal. You do not have to send in evidence but it can help your appeal.
evidence.para1: You should send any evidence to the tribunal as soon as you can. This is so the tribunal have time to consider it before making a decision on your appeal.

medicalEvidenceDesc.para1: This type of evidence is useful in appeals where you want to show you have a medical condition. A letter from your doctor, physiotherapist, social worker or hospital consultant can help prove this. A useful letter will explain how your condition affects your life. It should also be focussed on the time that DWP made their decision about your entitlement to the benefit. Letters which just show you had an appointment are not useful.
medicalEvidenceDesc.para2: Please be aware your doctor may charge you for writing a letter. The tribunal cannot reimburse you for these.

writtenStatementDesc.para1: Someone who lives with you or knows you well you could write a statement or letter. A useful statement describes how your condition affects your life and includes the types of activities you can and cannot do. It should be their own view. It should also be focussed on the time that the DWP made their decision about your entitlement to benefits.
writtenStatementDesc.para2: It can be written by hand or on a computer but it should be signed by the person who wrote it. It should also say what their relationship is to you.

photographsDesc.para1: Sometimes a photo can be useful to help the tribunal panel see how your medical condition affects your life. For example, you could take a picture of any modifications in your home or aids you use to help you move. Do not send in any photos of your body.

evidence.whatYouSayTitle: What you say at the hearing

whatYouSayDesc.para1: What you say at the hearing can be the most useful form of evidence. The tribunal will listen to what you say to help them make a decision on your appeal.
whatYouSayDesc.para2: If you have a carer or someone who supports you at home, you could ask them to come and tell the tribunal about your condition. You should check that they are willing to come and they are available on the day.

sendingEvidenceDesc.para1: You can provide evidence using any of the options in the Provide Evidence tab, as soon as possible. This is so the tribunal have time to read it before they make a decision.
sendingEvidenceDesc.para2: Or you can post your evidence to the address below.
sendingEvidenceDesc.para3: Make sure you include the ‘document cover sheet’. This helps us match your evidence with your appeal. You received this cover sheet in the first letter that was sent to you about your appeal.

claimExpenses.title: Claiming expenses to attend your hearing
claimExpenses.entry: You may be able to claim back some of the money you spend on attending your hearing.
claimExpenses.para1: You should use public transport where possible. Keep your travel tickets and bring them with you to your hearing. You’ll be given a claim form to fill out by the tribunal clerk.
claimExpenses.para2: If you have a health condition or disability which means you can’t get yourself to the hearing then you might be able to claim for a taxi. You’ll need to get authorisation first by phoning 0300 123 1142.

hearing.title: What to expect at your appeal hearing
hearing.entry: Your hearing is an opportunity for you to explain your benefit appeal in person. A tribunal panel will consider everything you tell them and make an impartial decision on your appeal. The tribunal panel are independent from the Department of Work and Pensions (DWP).
hearing.imageText: A tribunal hearing, with a judge and doctor. There will also be a disability expert in some benefit appeals.

beforeHearingDesc.para1: Make sure you have all the documents that relate to your appeal. You should have received these in the post from DWP as a numbered ‘bundle’ of documents. Bring these with you to the hearing.
beforeHearingDesc.para2: You should plan to arrive at the hearing venue at least 15 minutes before it starts. Your hearing may go ahead without you if you are late, or be postponed to a different day.

arriveDesc.para1: You’ll be greeted by a tribunal clerk. They’ll take care of you at the hearing venue and answer any questions you have. They will also give you a form so you can claim back any money you spend on attending the hearing. Read about claiming expenses for your hearing.

hearingRoomDesc.para1: The tribunal clerk will take you into the hearing room. The tribunal panel will be sat behind a table. You’ll be invited to sit opposite them. If you have someone to support you or to give evidence, they’ll sit next to you.

peopleInTheRoomDesc.para1: The tribunal panel is made up of 2 or 3 people, depending on which benefit you are appealing. The panel will consider both sides of the appeal and make an impartial decision. They are independent from DWP.
peopleInTheRoomDesc.para2: The judge runs the hearing and will explain what happens. They’ll also take notes of what is said during the hearing. The doctor provides their medical knowledge. If there is a disability expert in your hearing then they will provide their knowledge of disability issues and how disability affects people.

duringHearingDesc.para1: The tribunal panel will ask you some straightforward questions. This is your opportunity to explain your side of the appeal. They will listen to everything you tell them. They may also ask DWP some questions. The whole hearing usually lasts about an hour.
duringHearingDesc.para2: It’s important that you submit all your evidence well before the hearing so the tribunal panel have time to review it. If they receive it too late they may have to postpone your hearing until a different day.

gettingDecisionDesc.para1: After you’ve answered all the questions you’ll be asked to wait outside while the tribunal panel discuss your appeal. You’ll then be asked back into the room to be told the decision.
gettingDecisionDesc.para2: The judge will explain whether you’re entitled to the benefit and if so, at what level.
gettingDecisionDesc.para3: Sometimes the tribunal need more time to make a decision. If that happens the decision about your appeal will be posted to you.

dwpDesc.para1: A representative from DWP might be there. They are not part of the tribunal panel and are there to speak on behalf of DWP. They will not be the person who made the decision about your entitlement to benefits.

representatives.title: Representatives
representatives.entry: You can appoint someone as a ‘representative’ to help you with your benefit appeal, if you think you will not be able to manage the appeal by yourself.

whatList.item1: give you advice in relation to your appeal
whatList.item2: help you submit your appeal or prepare evidence
whatList.item3: act on your behalf during the appeal (they should ask your permission first)

representatives.para1: Anyone can be a representative, including friends and family. A good representative will know about the benefits system and can advise you on the law.
representatives.para2: You can get a representative at your local advice centre, law centre or Citizens Advice You will need to register them with the tribunal.

representative.title: Registering a representative
representative.para1: We need your written authority to register someone as your representative. You can provide this information via any of the options in the Provide Evidence tab.
representative.para2: Please include your representative’s name, address and contact details (phone or email). If you provide their email address and mobile phone number, they will also get regular updates.

withdrawAppeal.title: Withdrawing your appeal
withdrawAppeal.entry: You can withdraw your appeal at any time. DWP will be notified that you no longer want to appeal against their decision. The hearing for your appeal will be cancelled, if one has been arranged.
withdrawAppeal.para1: You should talk to your representative or someone who knows about your appeal for advice on whether you should withdraw your appeal.
withdrawAppeal.para2: If you still want to withdraw your appeal then should let the tribunal know as soon as possible.
withdrawAppeal.para3: You can provide this information via any of the options in the Provide Evidence tab . Or contact us on the number below.

about.header: Anfon tystiolaeth i gefnogi eich apêl
about.leadParagraph: Tystiolaeth yw unrhyw wybodaeth sy’n cefnogi’ch apêl, fel llythyr, datganiad ysgrifenedig neu adroddiad meddygol. Mae’n helpu’r tribiwnlys i ddeall ffeithiau eich apêl.

intro.para1: Dylech anfon unrhyw dystiolaeth sydd gennych cyn gynted ag sy’n bosibl. Mae hyn er mwyn caniatáu amser i'r tribiwnlys ei hystyried cyn iddynt wneud penderfyniad ynghylch eich apêl.
intro.para2: Gallwch anfon tystiolaeth ar-lein neu drwy’r post. Cewch ragor o wybodaeth am sut i'w hanfon ar waelod y dudalen hon.

medical.para1: Mae’r math hwn o dystiolaeth yn helpu’r tribiwnlys i ddeall eich cyflwr o safbwynt gweithiwr proffesiynol meddygol. Er enghraifft, llythyrau rydych wedi’u cael gan eich ymgynghorydd ysbyty, eich meddyg, eich ffisiotherapydd neu’ch gweithiwr cymdeithasol. Mae llythyr defnyddiol yn egluro sut oedd eich cyflwr yn effeithio ar eich bywyd ar yr adeg gwnaed y penderfyniad gan y DWP. Nid yw llythyrau apwyntiadau yn ddefnyddiol.
medical.para2: Os nad oes gennych unrhyw lythyrau ac rydych yn credu y byddai cael un yn eich helpu gyda’ch apêl, gallwch ofyn i’r gweithiwr proffesiynol meddygol sydd wedi bod yn trin eich cyflwr i ysgrifennu un. Sylwch, gallant godi ffi arnoch am wneud hyn a gall gymryd cryn amser i'w drefnu. Ni all y tribiwnlys dalu am y rhain.

statement.para1: Gall rhywun sy’n byw gyda chi neu’n eich adnabod yn dda ysgrifennu datganiad. Mae datganiad defnyddiol yn disgrifio sut mae eich cyflwr yn effeithio ar eich bywyd ac yn cynnwys y mathau o weithgareddau y gallwch eu gwneud a’r rhai na allwch eu gwneud. Dylai’r datganiad gyfleu eu safbwynt nhw.
statement.para2: Gellir ei ysgrifennu â llaw neu ei deipio ond rhaid i'r unigolyn sydd wedi’i ysgrifennu ei lofnodi. Dylai hefyd nodi beth yw eu perthynas â chi.

photographic.para1: Bydd ffotograff defnyddiol yn dangos sut mae eich cyflwr yn effeithio ar eich bywyd, er enghraifft, gallwch dynnu llun o unrhyw declynnau cymorth rydych yn eu defnyddio i'ch helpu i symud. Peidiwch ag anfon unrhyw ffotograffau o’ch corff.

oral.para1: Gelwir yr hyn rydych chi neu unrhyw un arall yn ei ddweud mewn gwrandawiad (os byddwch yn cael un) yn ‘dystiolaeth lafar’. Bydd y tribiwnlys yn defnyddio’r hyn a gaiff ei ddweud i’w helpu i wneud penderfyniad ynghylch eich apêl.
oral.para2: Os byddwch yn cael gwrandawiad yna gallwch wahodd rhywun sy’n eich adnabod yn dda i ddod iddo ac i ddweud wrth y tribiwnlys am eich cyflwr. Dylech wneud yn siwr eu bod yn fodlon dod a'u bod ar gael ar ddyddiad y gwrandawiad.

evidence.title: Anfon tystiolaeth i gefnogi eich apêl
evidence.entry: Tystiolaeth yw unrhyw wybodaeth sy’n cefnogi’ch apêl, fel llythyr, datganiad ysgrifenedig neu adroddiad meddygol. Gall helpu’r tribiwnlys i ddeall ffeithiau eich apêl. Nid oes rhaid ichi anfon tystiolaeth ond gall helpu eich apêl.
evidence.para1: Dylech anfon unrhyw dystiolaeth i'r tribiwnlys cyn gynted ag sy’n bosibl. Mae hyn er mwyn rhoi amser i'r tribiwnlys ei hystyried cyn iddynt wneud penderfyniad ynghylch eich apêl.

medicalEvidenceDesc.para1: Mae’r math hwn o dystiolaeth yn ddefnyddiol mewn achosion lle’r ydych eisiau dangos bod gennych gyflwr meddygol. Gall llythyr gan eich meddyg, ffisiotherapydd, gweithiwr cymdeithasol neu ymgynghorydd ysbyty helpu i brofi hyn. Bydd llythyr defnyddiol yn egluro sut mae eich cyflwr yn effeithio ar eich bywyd. Dylai hefyd ganolbwyntio ar yr adeg y gwnaeth DWP eu penderfyniad ynghylch eich hawl i gael y budd-dal. Nid yw llythyrau apwyntiadau yn ddefnyddiol.
medicalEvidenceDesc.para2: Sylwch, gall eich meddyg godi ffi arnoch am ysgrifennu llythyr. Ni all y tribiwnlys ad-dalu'r costau hyn.

writtenStatementDesc.para1: Gall rhywun sy’n byw gyda chi neu rywun sy’n eich adnabod yn dda ysgrifennu datganiad neu lythyr. Mae datganiad defnyddiol yn disgrifio sut mae eich cyflwr yn effeithio ar eich bywyd a’r mathau o weithgareddau y gallwch eu gwneud a’r rhai na allwch eu gwneud. Dylai’r datganiad gyfleu eu safbwynt nhw. Dylai hefyd ganolbwyntio ar yr adeg y gwnaeth DWP eu penderfyniad ynghylch eich hawl i gael y budd-dal.
writtenStatementDesc.para2: Gellir ei ysgrifennu â llaw neu ei deipio ond rhaid i'r unigolyn sydd wedi’i ysgrifennu ei lofnodi. Dylai hefyd nodi beth yw eu perthynas gyda chi.

photographsDesc.para1: Weithiau gall ffotograff fod yn ddefnyddiol i helpu i ddangos i'r tribiwnlys sut mae eich cyflwr meddygol yn effeithio ar eich bywyd. Er enghraifft, gallwch dynnu llun o unrhyw addasiadau yn eich cartref, neu unrhyw declynnau cymorth rydych yn eu defnyddio i'ch helpu i symud. Peidiwch ag anfon unrhyw ffotograffau o’ch corff.

evidence.whatYouSayTitle: Yr hyn byddwch yn ei ddweud yn y gwrandawiad

whatYouSayDesc.para1: Gall yr hyn byddwch yn ei ddweud yn y gwrandawiad fod y math mwyaf defnyddiol o dystiolaeth. Bydd y tribiwnlys yn gwrando ar yr hyn byddwch yn ei ddweud i'w helpu i wneud penderfyniad ynghylch eich apêl.
whatYouSayDesc.para2: Os oes gennych ofalwr neu rywun sy’n eich cefnogi adref, gallwch ofyn iddynt ddod i'r gwrandawiad a dweud wrth y tribiwnlys am eich cyflwr. Dylech wneud yn siwr eu bod yn fodlon dod a’u bod ar gael ar ddyddiad y gwrandawiad.

sendingEvidenceDesc.para1: Gallwch ddarparu tystiolaeth trwy ddefnyddio unrhyw un o’r opsiynau yn y tab Darparu Tystiolaeth a dylech wneud hynny cyn gynted â phosib er mwyn i’r tribiwnlys gael amser i’w darllen cyn gwneud penderfyniad.
sendingEvidenceDesc.para2: Neu gallwch bostio’ch tystiolaeth i’r cyfeiriad a nodir isod.
sendingEvidenceDesc.para3: Gwnewch yn siŵr eich bod yn cynnwys y ‘dalen flaen dogfen’ fel y gallwn baru’r dystiolaeth gyda’ch apêl. Cawsoch y daflen flaen hon gyda’r llythyr cyntaf a anfonwyd atoch ynghylch eich apêl.

hearing.title: Beth i'w ddisgwyl yn eich gwrandawiad apêl
hearing.entry: Mae eich gwrandawiad yn gyfle ichi egluro eich apêl budd-dal yn bersonol. Bydd panel tribiwnlys yn ystyried popeth byddwch yn ei ddweud wrthynt ac yn gwneud penderfyniad diduedd ynghylch eich apêl. Mae panel y tribiwnlys yn annibynnol o'r Adran Gwaith a Phensiynau (DWP).
hearing.imageText: Bydd panel y tribiwnlys yn cynnwys barnwr a meddyg. Bydd yna arbenigwr anabledd hefyd mewn rhai apeliadau budd-dal.

beforeHearingDesc.para1: Gwnewch yn siwr bod gennych yr holl ddogfennau sy’n ymwneud â’ch apêl. Dylech fod wedi cael y rhain drwy’r post gan DWP fel ‘bwndel’ o ddogfennau wedi’u rhifo. Dewch â’r rhain gyda chi i'r gwrandawiad.
beforeHearingDesc.para2: Dylech anelu at fod yn y ganolfan wrandawiadau o leiaf 15 munud cyn i'r gwrandawiad ddechrau. Gall eich gwrandawiad fynd yn ei flaen hebddoch chi os byddwch yn hwyr, neu gall gael ei ohirio i'w gynnal ar ddiwrnod arall.

arriveDesc.para1: Bydd clerc y tribiwnlys yn eich croesawu. Byddant yn gofalu amdanoch chi yn y ganolfan wrandawiadau ac yn ateb unrhyw gwestiynau y bydd gennych. Byddant hefyd yn rhoi ffurflen ichi ar gyfer hawlio yn ôl unrhyw arian byddwch yn ei wario o ganlyniad i fynychu’r gwrandawiad.Darllenwch fwy am hawlio treuliau ar gyfer eich gwrandawiad.

hearingRoomDesc.para1: Bydd clerc y tribiwnlys yn eich hebrwng i'r ystafell wrandawiadau. Bydd panel y tribiwnlys yn eistedd y tu ôl i fwrdd. Byddwch yn cael eich gwahodd i eistedd gyferbyn â’r panel. Os bydd rhywun wedi dod gyda chi i’ch cefnogi neu i roi tystiolaeth, byddant yn eistedd wrth eich ymyl.

peopleInTheRoomDesc.para1: Mae panel y tribiwnlys yn cynnwys 2 neu 3 o bobl, yn ddibynnol ar y math o fudd-dal sy’n destun yr apêl. Bydd y panel yn ystyried dwy ochr yr apêl ac yn gwneud penderfyniad diduedd. Maent yn annibynnol o DWP.
peopleInTheRoomDesc.para2: Y barnwr sy’n rheoli’r gwrandawiad a bydd yn egluro beth sy’n digwydd. Byddant hefyd yn cymryd nodiadau o’r hyn sy’n cael ei ddweud yn ystod y gwrandawiad. Mae'r meddyg yno i ddarparu gwybodaeth feddygol. Os bydd arbenigwr anabledd yn eich gwrandawiad, yna bydd yn darparu gwybodaeth am faterion anabledd a sut mae anabledd yn effeithio ar bobl.

duringHearingDesc.para1: Bydd panel y tribiwnlys yn gofyn rhywfaint o gwestiynau syml ichi. Dyma eich cyfle i egluro eich ochr chi o’r apêl. Byddant yn gwrando ar bopeth rydych yn ei ddweud wrthynt. Efallai byddant yn gofyn cwestiynau i DWP hefyd. Fel arfer bydd y gwrandawiad cyfan yn cymryd tua awr.
duringHearingDesc.para2: Mae’n bwysig eich bod yn cyflwyno’ch tystiolaeth i gyd cyn y gwrandawiad fel bod gan banel y tribiwnlys amser i'w hadolygu. Os byddant yn ei chael yn rhy hwyr, efallai bydd rhaid iddynt ohirio eich gwrandawiad i'w gynnal ar ddiwrnod arall.

gettingDecisionDesc.para1: Ar ôl ichi ateb yr holl gwestiynau, gofynnir ichi aros y tu allan tra bydd panel y tribiwnlys yn trafod eich apêl. Yna gofynnir ichi ddod yn ôl i mewn i'r ystafell i gael gwybod beth yw’r penderfyniad.
gettingDecisionDesc.para2: Bydd y barnwr yn egluro ichi a oes gennych hawl i gael y budd-dal, ac os felly, ar ba lefel.
gettingDecisionDesc.para3: Weithiau mae’r tribiwnlys angen mwy o amser i wneud penderfyniad. Os bydd hynny’n digwydd, bydd y penderfyniad ynghylch eich apêl yn cael ei bostio atoch.

dwpDesc.para1: Gall cynrychiolydd o DWP fod yna. Nid ydynt yn rhan o banel y tribiwnlys ac maent yna i siarad ar ran DWP. Nid y cynrychiolydd fydd yr unigolyn a wnaeth y penderfyniad ynghylch eich hawl i gael budd-daliadau.

representatives.title: Cynrychiolwyr
representatives.entry: Gallwch benodi rhywun fel ‘cynrychiolydd’ i'ch helpu gyda’ch apêl budd-dal, os ydych yn credu na fyddwch yn gallu delio â’r apêl ar eich pen eich hun.

whatList.item2: eich helpu i gyflwyno eich apêl neu i baratoi tystiolaeth
whatList.item3: gweithredu ar eich rhan yn ystod yr apêl (dylent ofyn am eich caniatâd yn gyntaf)

representatives.para1: Gall unrhyw un fod yn gynrychiolydd, yn cynnwys ffrind neu aelod o’ch teulu. Bydd cynrychiolydd da yn gyfarwydd â’r system budd-daliadau ac yn gallu rhoi cyngor ichi ar y gyfraith.
representatives.para2: Gallwch gael cynrychiolydd yn eich canolfan gynghori leol, canolfan y gyfraith leol neu ganolfan Cyngor ar Bopeth leol. Bydd arnoch angen eu cofrestru gyda’r tribiwnlys.

representative.title: Cofrestru cynrychiolydd
representative.para1: Mae arnom angen eich awdurdod ysgrifenedig i gofrestru rhywun fel eich cynrychiolydd. Gallwch ddarparu’r wybodaeth hon trwy unrhyw un o’r opsiynau yn y tab Darparu Tystiolaeth.
representative.para2: Cofiwch gynnwys enw eich cynrychiolydd, eu cyfeiriad a’u manylion cyswllt (ffôn neu e-bost). Os byddwch yn darparu eu cyfeiriad e-bost â’u rhif ffôn symudol, byddant yn cael diweddariadau yn rheolaidd.

withdrawAppeal.title: Tynnu eich apêl yn ôl
withdrawAppeal.entry: Gallwch dynnu eich apêl yn ôl ar unrhyw adeg. Bydd DWP yn cael gwybod nad ydych eisiau apelio yn erbyn eu penderfyniad mwyach. Bydd y gwrandawiad ar gyfer eich apêl yn cael ei ganslo, os oedd un wedi’i drefnu.
withdrawAppeal.para1: Dylech siarad gyda’ch cynrychiolydd neu rywun sy’n gwybod am eich apêl i gael cyngor ar p’un a ddylech dynnu eich apêl yn ôl ai peidio.
withdrawAppeal.para2: Os ydych dal eisiau tynnu eich apêl yn ôl, yna dylech roi gwybod i'r tribiwnlys cyn gynted ag sy’n bosibl.
withdrawAppeal.para3: Gallwch ddarparu’r wybodaeth hon trwy unrhyw un o’r opsiynau yn y tab Darparu Tystiolaeth, neu cysylltwch â ni ar y rhif isod.
